comments.body: we want to find places where currently a KeyError is raised and change them in the tests.

I've now done that.  My way of doing that was to make UnsortedIndexError a subclass of ValueError, run nosetests to see where it complained, and then change those tests accordingly.  Then I switched UnsortedIndexError back to being a subclass of KeyError.

diffHunk:

        # GH 11897
        mi = pd.MultiIndex.from_tuples([('z', 'a'), ('x', 'a'), ('y', 'b'),
                                        ('x', 'b'), ('y', 'a'), ('z', 'b')],
                                       names=['one', 'two'])

comments.body: Why do we xfail this? (I mean, why don't we keep asserting for now that it is float)

The assertions compare a correctly built index (``float64`` data in ``Float64Index``) with an invalid index (``float64`` data in ``Int64Index``, due to #17924 ). Maybe I'm missing something, but it's not obvious to me what we would assert - plus, I see it as an added value to ``xfail`` for a buggy behavior.
can you add an explicit test for the issue, e.g that you are raising (use the example from the original issue).
